posts.post_content:
It's essentially a [Leonin Skyhunter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leonin Skyhunter) that you can summon on turn 3 to make room for your turn 2 [Cerodon Yearling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cerodon Yearling).  
It's also ![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol), making it strictly cooler.

It's essentially a Leonin Skyhunter that you can summon on turn 3 to make room for your turn 2 Cerodon Yearling.

Posted By: Blackworm_Bloodworm (2/1/2011 6:26:47 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I prefer him hands down to cerodon yearling. Cerodon might seem like the better, with a 1 mana cheaper cost and a typically stronger ability (vigilance vs. flying), but without evasion he just ends up smacking into ground troops like a dumb lummox. Skyknight, on the other hand, has won me almost all of my multiplayer matches by being able to pop out of nowhere and deal the finishing blow with some help from a balefire liege, a sunforger, or a scourge of the nobilis.  
  
I've used both and fought against both, and the yearling almost never manages to get its punches in, while the skyknight manages to finds the perfect gap to deal his damage.  
  
Also, this card should practically marry Boros Garrison. They really were made for each other.
posts.html:
I prefer him hands down to cerodon yearling. Cerodon might seem like the better, with a 1 mana cheaper cost and a typically stronger ability (vigilance vs. flying), but without evasion he just ends up smacking into ground troops like a dumb lummox. Skyknight, on the other hand, has won me almost all of my multiplayer matches by being able to pop out of nowhere and deal the finishing blow with some help from a balefire liege, a sunforger, or a scourge of the nobilis.

I've used both and fought against both, and the yearling almost never manages to get its punches in, while the skyknight manages to finds the perfect gap to deal his damage.

Also, this card should practically marry Boros Garrison. They really were made for each other.

Posted By: iraah9 (10/17/2010 8:16:46 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I love this card. He has flies over early chumps, and the art is fantastic. I don't think he has ever spent time in my storage boxes, as he has always been in my decks ever since I got him in the Boros precon deck.  
  
He also makes for a mean curve:  
T1: [Boros Recruit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boros Recruit)  
T2: [Boros Swiftblade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boros Swiftblade) or [Cerodon Yearling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cerodon Yearling)  
T3: This or [Hearthfire Hobgoblin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hearthfire Hobgoblin)  
T4: [Brion Stoutarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Brion Stoutarm) or a [Scourge of the Nobilis](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Scourge of the Nobilis) on either the Skynight or a first/double-striker, gain tons of life  
  
Not only is he incredibly aggressive and efficient, he is also and tremendously fun.
posts.html:

T3: This or Hearthfire Hobgoblin

Not only is he incredibly aggressive and efficient, he is also and tremendously fun.

Posted By: RJDroid (9/8/2011 12:00:54 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I'm in love with this card!
  
Jim Murray must've been blessed by some higher power when draWINg this. Colors, buildings, leggionaire, his mount, and - oh - the marching boros below. You can't argue with Razia on this. Breathtaking!
  
And what an elegant ability pair, perfectly fitting the flavour and overall Boros guild style. Even if it wasn't strongly playable, i would still play it!
  
P.S. It's a knight, so... you know, the obvious tribal synergies... [Auriok Steelshaper](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Auriok Steelshaper), [Kinsbaile Cavalier](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kinsbaile Cavalier). Maybe something crazy like [Haakon, Stromgald Scourge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Haakon, Stromgald Scourge)...

And what an elegant ability pair, perfectly fitting the flavour and overall Boros guild style. Even if it wasn't strongly playable, i would still play it!

posts.post_content:
Blue-Black I BELIEVE may be the most hated color combination in Magic, with decks that are either horribly broken beyond belief (think artifacts. or better yet don't. #shudder#.) or decks that look like they're supposed to be good, but can't quite get there any more because fast creatures are too good now. So somebody's always whining about power-level either way.   
  
part-Green builds of Black/x that break the GAME ZONE: GRAVEYARD (that's right folks, an entire zone of the game is broken, just in case you lived under a rock and didn't know that yet. Wait. living under a Rock deck, you probably know all about the graveyard. Moving along.)  
  
By contrast, Red/White seems to be the game's most popular creature type. It combines the 'Hulk SMASH!' power and attitude of Lightning Bolt and Kird Ape with the honor and heroism of White Knight and Angels. Everybody loves to be the good guy, and they love it even more when they get to kick ass instead of go the tragic tortured hero route. Red/White ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
most disipointing loss i have ever had:
  
   
my brother was playing a mono-black [Grave Pact](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grave Pact)/zombie tribal deck, me with red white.
  
   
he was down to no cretures and me with a [Bull Cerodon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bull Cerodon) ready to finish him off, he playes a [Rise from the Grave](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rise from the Grave) on my dead Skyknight Legionnaire and deals the last 2 damage to finish me off.

posts.post_content:
I prefer him hands down to cerodon yearling. Cerodon might seem like the better, with a 1 mana cheaper cost and a typically stronger ability (vigilance vs. flying), but without evasion he just ends up smacking into ground troops like a dumb lummox. Skyknight, on the other hand, has won me almost all of my multiplayer matches by being able to pop out of nowhere and deal the finishing blow with some help from a balefire liege, a sunforger, or a scourge of the nobilis.  
  
I've used both and fought against both, and the yearling almost never manages to get its punches in, while the skyknight manages to finds the perfect gap to deal his damage.  
  
Also, this card should practically marry Boros Garrison. They really were made for each other.
